Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with probably straight sides (side view unknown); underside bearing a hieroglyphic inscription naming Amun-Ra; inscription probably stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; pierced through diameter; faint traces of greenish glaze (though said to be unbaked and unglazed on the EEF distribution list); in yellowish beige paste; one side broken.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The inscription gives clearly the name of Amun-Ra (not men-ka-Ra, as suggested by Gorton, 104, B141). Numerous variants of the name of Amun-Ra were discovered on scarabs and scaraboids in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 89-93; Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 25 and 36), without including all the different cryptographic writings of Amun on Naukratis scarabs and scaraboids. This scaraboid belongs to a type produced at Naukratis and widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, Type XXVIII B, subtype B140-147, see especially B141 for this piece; on the various productions of the “Scarab Factory”, see Webb forthcoming). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 93)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p.104, Type XXVIII B141)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.041) (phase 3)
Condition: Quite poor, chipped in various places and eroded
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4910 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
